case_vignette: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a fall from her bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on her way to work as she lost her balance, hitting her head on the sidewalk. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has nausea and a headache. She has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. She has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While performing the remainder of the physical examination the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I currently have nausea and a headache, and I've vomited twice in the last 30 minutes.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 27-year-old woman.
Did the headache come on suddenly or gradually?
The headache came on after I hit my head in a fall from my bicycle.
Do you have any dizziness, confusion, or loss of consciousness after the fall?
I did have an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes after the fall.
Do you currently have any issues with your vision, hearing, balance, or coordination?
I haven't mentioned any issues with my vision, hearing, balance, or coordination right now.
Are you on any medications, or do you have any existing medical conditions?
I take no medications and have no history of a serious illness.
Is there any part of your head that feels more tender or painful to touch since the fall?
There is a bruise on the right temporal side of my head.
Since the injury, have you noticed any fluid or blood leaking from your ears or nose?
I haven't mentioned anything about fluid or blood leaking from my ears or nose.
Final Diagnosis: Concussion with possible mild traumatic brain injury.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with nausea, a headache, and a history of vomiting twice in the last 30 minutes. She reports that the headache began after she hit her head in a fall from her bicycle and experienced a momentary loss of consciousness. She denies any issues with her vision, hearing, balance, or coordination at present. She has no history of serious illness, takes no medications, and has a bruise on the right temporal side of her head. There is no mention of fluid or blood leaking from her ears or nose.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis in this patient is a traumatic brain injury with possible intracranial hemorrhage.
